commit_message:
amqpdriver: remove a temporary hack around context

We now require that context is passed as a dict.

Change-Id: Id4afd4b18dc323bc340991e4ab02fae6f9cb5fcb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/59/70759/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rpc_amqp.pack_context(msg, ctxt)
deleted_lines: # FIXME(markmc): remove this temporary hack class Context(object): def __init__(self, d): self.d = d def to_dict(self): return self.d context = Context(ctxt) rpc_amqp.pack_context(msg, context)

named pagination, includes limit, marker_pair,
sort_keys and sort_directions.

And request a single marker pair passed from users and it should be
specific enough to identify only one object in the database.
Support multiple sort keys and sort directions combination.

It is part of bp/paginate-db-search.

Implements blueprint paginate-db-search

Change-Id: I08f8d73254ddcd9ce1522e343193d37f6ea6daa7

commit_message:
Change pagination related methods of mongodb and db2

Put all parameters for paginate query in one class,
named pagination, includes limit, primary_sort_dir,
marker_value, sort_keys and sort_dirs.
And request a single marker value passed from users and it should be
specific enough to identify only one object in the database.
Get_resource uses aggregation and not support pagination for now.
Support multiple sort keys and sort directions combination.

Changes also made to db2 to support multiple sort directions while
generate sort_instruction.

It is part of bp/paginate-db-search.

Implements blueprint paginate-db-search

Change-Id: I08f8d73254ddcd9ce1522e343193d37f6ea6daa7

deleted_lines: from ceilometer.storage.base import MultipleResultsFound marker_pairs = {'user_id': 'user-id-4'} marker_pairs) marker_pairs = {'user_id': 'user-id-foo'} marker_pairs) def test_get_marker_multiple(self): try: marker_pairs = {'project_id': 'project-id'} ret = impl_mongodb.Connection._get_marker(self.conn.db.resource, marker_pairs) self.assertEqual(ret['project_id'], 'project-id-foo') except MultipleResultsFound: self.assertTrue(True) marker_pairs = {'name': 'red-alert'} marker_pairs=marker_pairs) marker_pairs = {'name': 'user-id-foo'} marker_pairs) def test_alarm_get_marker_multiple(self): self.add_some_alarms() try: marker_pairs = {'user_id': 'me'} ret = impl_mongodb.Connection._get_marker(self.conn.db.alarm, marker_pairs) self.assertEqual(ret['counter_name'], 'counter-name-foo') except MultipleResultsFound: self.assertTrue(True)

subject: Creates the glance-swift user

This fix updates lib/swift to include the glance-swift user as
one of the users created in create_swift_accounts(). The
glance-swift user is required for glance to operate when

Change-Id: I40a8fa66d7da22a07211ad0d3bbe6a915fec2179

commit_message:
Creates the glance-swift user

This fix updates lib/swift to include the glance-swift user as
one of the users created in create_swift_accounts(). The
glance-swift user is required for glance to operate when
swift is present. Works for me.

Closes-Bug: 1279323
Change-Id: I40a8fa66d7da22a07211ad0d3bbe6a915fec2179
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/51/72951/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # service glance-swift admin GLANCE_SWIFT_USER=$(keystone user-create --name=glance-swift --pass="$SERVICE_PASSWORD" \ --tenant-id $SERVICE_TENANT --email=swift@example.com | grep " id " | get_field 2) die_if_not_set $LINENO GLANCE_SWIFT_USER "Failure creating glance-swift user" keystone user-role-add --user-id $GLANCE_SWIFT_USER --role-id $ADMIN_ROLE --tenant-id $SERVICE_TENANT

subject: Use six.moves.urllib.parse need module six

commit_message:
Use six.moves.urllib.parse instead of urlparse

To keep Python 3.x compatibility, use six.moves.urllib.parse to
replace urlparse.

Change-Id: I371499a286556c3e58515da71a3e02b97dad4acc

commit_message:
Improve help strings

Follow oslo.config style guide for help strings better to create
consistent help strings:
* Finish help strings with "."
* Add missing spaces between words
* Fix wording and capitalization

Co-Authored-By: Shilla Saebi <shilla.saebi@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I40a035bf0b0db0994e98a5601a4abafefbc879ea

commit_message:
Use working default settings for ec2 test

Devstack configures the path with cirros-0.3.1, but does not
configures the manifest file names with the new version, it leads
to the ec2 test cases are autoskiped.

It should be improved on devstack side as well, but looks like there are
other issues which needs to be addressed, but anyway the default tempest
config should be closer, to the actually used one.

Change-Id: I7a2b01b9f41c36b56f3f3768d9659a7d3c5aab61

commit_message:
Add qpid-python to requirements

Qpid is a supported messaging library, and without this it is
necessary to install it manually in order to use Qpid in some
environments, notably the one used by TripleO.

Change-Id: I5a855ed4b65efeed51e7b181105e1a8ccf3163f3
Closes-Bug: #1225191

commit_message:
Fixes ambiguous cli output between "None" and NoneType

Print hyphen(-) in python client output when attribute value is not
set so that it is distinguishable when "None" string is set and when
no attribute value is specified.

Change-Id: Id49250396df4159a64495e9e812ada81b76dfc74
Closes-Bug: #1266414
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/56/70656/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Dynamic pipelines for server configuration

This patch allows admins of systems who use software that
generates/controls swift config files to add items to an existing swift
configuration that uses the conf.d-style without intruding on the
managing system.  This is done by adding a new config file in the
config.d directory with a filter section declared in it, and explicitly
declaring the ordering dependencies of that filter with other items in
the pipeline.

Other features:

Dynamic pipelines rendered under conf.d only
Added config.d documentation to proxy-server man page

Change-Id: Id40841f8b007a1b3779704c4f43792c7ecc79dff

""", 'proxy-server.conf.d/app.conf': """ [app:proxy-server] use = egg:swift#proxy """, 'proxy-server.conf.d/catch-errors.conf': """ [filter:catch_errors] use = egg:swift#catch_errors pipeline = main pipeline = main [filter:healthcheck] use = egg:swift#healthcheck before = #start pipeline = main """, } # strip indent from test config contents config_dir = dict((f, dedent(c)) for (f, c) in f.write('[DEFAULT]\nswift_dir = %s' % conf_root) _fake_rings(conf_root) app, conf, logger, log_name = wsgi.init_request_processor( conf_dir, 'proxy-server') # verify pipeline def get_pipeline(app): yield app while hasattr(app, 'app'): app = app.app yield app def get_pipeline_class_names(app): for ware in get_pipeline(app): yield ware.__class__.__name__ expected_classnames = [ 'CatchErrorMiddleware', 'HealthCheckMiddleware', 'KeystoneAuth', 'TempAuth', 'Application'] pipeline_classnames = list(get_pipeline_class_names(app)) self.assertEquals(expected_classnames, pipeline_classnames) 'dynamic_pipelines': 'False',@contextmanager def temp_config(contents): with temptree(['proxy-server.conf']) as t: conf_dir = os.path.join(t, 'proxy-server.conf.d') os.mkdir(conf_dir) conf_file = os.path.join(conf_dir, 'default.conf') with open(conf_file, 'w') as f: f.write(contents) f.close() loader = wsgi.ConfigDirLoader(conf_dir) yield loader.parser class TestConfigParsing(unittest.TestCase): def setUp(self): self.basic_config = dedent(""" [DEFAULT] dynamic_pipelines = True [pipeline:main] pipeline = catch_errors proxy-server [app:proxy-server] use = egg:swift#proxy conn_timeout = 0.2 [filter:catch_errors] use = egg:swift#catch_errors """) def test_config_utility_methods(self): self.assertEquals('foo', wsgi.dequalify('foo')) self.assertEquals('foo', wsgi.dequalify('a:foo')) self.assertEquals('b:foo', wsgi.dequalify('a:b:foo')) self.assertEquals('filter:bar', wsgi.qualify('app', 'bar')) self.assertEquals('filter:b:bar', wsgi.qualify('app', 'b:bar')) self.assertEquals('app:app', wsgi.qualify('app', 'app')) self.assertEquals(['foo', 'bar'], wsgi.dequalify_names(['a:foo', 'bar'])) self.assertEquals(['filter:a:foo', 'app:app'], wsgi.qualify_names('app', ['a:foo', 'app'])) def test_basic_interpolation(self): config_text = dedent(self.basic_config) + dedent(""" [filter:attheend] pipeline = main after = between [filter:between] pipeline = main before = proxy-server after = catch_errors [filter:atthestart] pipeline = main before = catch_errors """) with temp_config(config_text) as config: pipeline = config.get('pipeline:main', 'pipeline') expected = 'atthestart catch_errors between attheend proxy-server' self.assertEquals(expected, pipeline) def test_provides(self): config_text = dedent(self.basic_config) + dedent(""" [filter:kerberos] pipeline = main provides = authentication before = proxy-server provides:authorization after = catch_errors [filter:ldap] pipeline = main provides = authorization before = proxy-server after = provides:authentication catch_errors [filter:coffee] pipeline = main provides = java before = provides:authentication provides:authorization after = catch_errors """) with temp_config(config_text) as config: pipeline = config.get('pipeline:main', 'pipeline') expected = 'catch_errors coffee kerberos ldap proxy-server' self.assertEquals(expected, pipeline) def test_nonexistent_constraints(self): config_text = dedent(self.basic_config) + dedent(""" [filter:deluded] pipeline = main before = doesnotexist after = provides:nonexistent [filter:fool] pipeline = main provides = authorization before = imaginary, figmental after = illusive; fictional; hallucinatory """) with temp_config(config_text) as config: pipeline = config.get('pipeline:main', 'pipeline') expected = set(['catch_errors', 'proxy-server', 'deluded', 'fool']) actual = set(re.split('\s+', pipeline)) self.assertEquals(expected, actual) def test_multiple_pipelines(self): config_text = dedent(self.basic_config) + dedent(""" [composite:superproxy] use = egg:swift#superproxy [pipeline:secondary] pipeline = process_successes superproxy [pipeline:shouldbeignored] pipeline = proxy-server [filter:shortbus] pipeline = main after = catch_errors process_successes before = proxy-server superproxy [filter:amalgamut] pipeline = main secondary before = catch_errors process_successes [filter:not_present_in_a_pipeline] before = catch_errors [filter:targets_a_nonexistent_pipeline] pipeline = doesnotexist before = catch_errors """) with temp_config(config_text) as config: pipeline = config.get('pipeline:main', 'pipeline') expected = 'amalgamut catch_errors shortbus proxy-server' self.assertEquals(expected, pipeline) pipeline = config.get('pipeline:secondary', 'pipeline') expected = 'amalgamut process_successes superproxy' self.assertEquals(expected, pipeline) pipeline = config.get('pipeline:shouldbeignored', 'pipeline') self.assertEquals('proxy-server', pipeline) def test_special_symbols(self): config_text = dedent(self.basic_config) + dedent(""" [filter:early] pipeline = main provides = authentication before = #start [filter:yet-earlier] pipeline = main provides = authentication before = #start early [filter:late] pipeline = main provides = authorization after = #end [filter:yet-later] pipeline = main after = #end """) with temp_config(config_text) as config: pipeline = config.get('pipeline:main', 'pipeline') expected = 'yet-earlier early catch_errors ' + \ 'late yet-later proxy-server' self.assertEquals(expected, pipeline) def test_duplicate_items(self): config_text = dedent(self.basic_config) + dedent(""" [pipeline:duplicates] pipeline = filtera filterb filtera filterb proxy-server [filter:filtera] pipeline = duplicates [filter:filterb] pipeline = duplicates """) with temp_config(config_text) as config: pipeline = config.get('pipeline:duplicates', 'pipeline') expected = 'filtera filterb filtera filterb proxy-server' self.assertEquals(expected, pipeline) def test_nothing_goes_after_app(self): config_text = dedent(self.basic_config) + dedent(""" [filter:after_app] pipeline = main after = proxy-server """) try: with temp_config(config_text): pass except Exception as e: self.assertEquals(wsgi.ConfigFileError, e.__class__) def test_must_have_static_pipeline(self): config_text = dedent(self.basic_config) + dedent(""" [pipeline:empty] [app:proxy-server] pipeline = empty [filter:filtera] pipeline = empty after = proxy-server """) try: with temp_config(config_text): pass except Exception as e: self.assertEquals(wsgi.ConfigFileError, e.__class__) def test_circular_dependencies(self): config_text = dedent(self.basic_config) + dedent(""" commit_message:
Initial ceilometer integration

Added two new mgmt API calls for retrieve instances/backups statistics.

Change-Id: I269b374e3af72ceeae67eecc19f3571653aa5575
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-troveclient refs/changes/80/70780/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Mirantis, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import testtools import mock from troveclient.v1 import stats """ Unit tests for stats.py """ class StatsTest(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(StatsTest, self).setUp() def side_effect_func(path, inst): return path, inst self.orig_instances__list = stats.InstancesStats._list self.orig_backups__list = stats.BackupsStats._list stats.InstancesStats._list = mock.Mock(side_effect=side_effect_func) stats.BackupsStats._list = mock.Mock(side_effect=side_effect_func) self.stats_instances = stats.InstancesStats(mock.Mock()) self.stats_backups = stats.BackupsStats(mock.Mock()) def tearDown(self): super(StatsTest, self).tearDown() stats.InstancesStats._list = self.orig_instances__list stats.BackupsStats._list = self.orig_backups__list def test_instances_list(self): self.assertEqual(('/mgmt/stats/instances', 'instances'), self.stats_instances.list()) def test_instances_list_by_tenant(self): self.assertEqual(('/mgmt/stats/instances/test_tenant', 'instances'), self.stats_instances.get('test_tenant')) def test_backups_list(self): self.assertEqual(('/mgmt/stats/backups', 'backups'), self.stats_backups.list()) def test_backups_list_by_tenant(self): self.assertEqual(('/mgmt/stats/backups/test_tenant', 'backups'), self.stats_backups.get('test_tenant'))

commit_message:
Initial ceilometer integration

Added two new mgmt API routes for retrieve instances/backups statistics.

Change-Id: Iade811884c0a898173b757be07b6e97f5ffc4d22
Implemets: blueprint ceilometer-integration

Various bugs have been spotted in running
the docker registry, both by users and in
CI. It will be easier to debug, especially for CI,

commit_message:
Print docker-registry log upon failure

Various bugs have been spotted in running
the docker registry, both by users and in
CI. It will be easier to debug, especially for CI,
if the failure were visible in logs.

Upon a failed lauch of the docker-registry,
we'll now print the registry's log to STDOUT.

fixes bug #1274984

Change-Id: I5c06163085059223b79c5ed8ab2036031a6fd340
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/66/70366/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cid=$(docker run -d -p ${DOCKER_REGISTRY_PORT}:5000 \ $DOCKER_REGISTRY_IMAGE_NAME ./docker-registry/run.sh) echo "Failure launching docker-registry. Printing registry logs:" docker logs $cid
deleted_lines: docker run -d -p ${DOCKER_REGISTRY_PORT}:5000 \ $DOCKER_REGISTRY_IMAGE_NAME ./docker-registry/run.sh

deleted_lines: from nova.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy import utils as sqlalchemyutilsdef model_query(context, model, *args, **kwargs): """Query helper that accounts for context's `read_deleted` field. :param context: context to query under :param use_slave: If true, use slave_connection :param session: if present, the session to use :param read_deleted: if present, overrides context's read_deleted field. :param project_only: if present and context is user-type, then restrict query to match the context's project_id. If set to 'allow_none', restriction includes project_id = None. :param base_model: Where model_query is passed a "model" parameter which is not a subclass of NovaBase, we should pass an extra base_model parameter that is a subclass of NovaBase and corresponds to the model parameter. """ use_slave = kwargs.get('use_slave') or False if CONF.database.slave_connection == '': use_slave = False session = kwargs.get('session') or get_session(slave_session=use_slave) read_deleted = kwargs.get('read_deleted') or context.read_deleted project_only = kwargs.get('project_only', False) def issubclassof_nova_base(obj): return isinstance(obj, type) and issubclass(obj, models.NovaBase) base_model = model if not issubclassof_nova_base(base_model): base_model = kwargs.get('base_model', None) if not issubclassof_nova_base(base_model): raise Exception(_("model or base_model parameter should be " "subclass of NovaBase")) query = session.query(model, *args) default_deleted_value = base_model.__mapper__.c.deleted.default.arg if read_deleted == 'no': query = query.filter(base_model.deleted == default_deleted_value) elif read_deleted == 'yes': pass # omit the filter to include deleted and active elif read_deleted == 'only': query = Change-Id: I9c8f82d500bcff3dd82a34a18b5f76813fbc4d4a
"}]
commit_message:
Refactor trusts format expires_at

Formatting a trusts expires_at was done in two distinct places,
to achieve the same result.
Give format_expires_at it's own function, and let other functions
call it, as necessary.

Change-Id: I9c8f82d500bcff3dd82a34a18b5f76813fbc4d4a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/01/72601/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._format_expires_at(trust) def _format_expires_at(self, trust): if trust.get('expires_at') is not None: time = timeutils.isotime(trust['expires_at'], subsecond=True) trust['expires_at'] = time def _fill_in_roles(self, context, trust, all_roles): self._format_expires_at(new_trust) self._format_expires_at(trust)
deleted_lines: def _fill_in_roles(self, context, trust, all_roles): if trust.get('expires_at') is not None: trust['expires_at'] = (timeutils.isotime (trust['expires_at'], subsecond=True)) if trust.get('expires_at') is not None: trust['expires_at'] = (timeutils.isotime (trust['expires_at'], subsecond=True))

subject: Parse JSON in ovs_lib.get_vif_port_by_id
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-16 23:56:26.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/linux/ovs_lib.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/openvswitch/test_ovs_lib.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/3d24fe5710cbea6d7d1f88c3476f4a856347ab5e', 'message': 'Parse JSON in ovs_lib.get_vif_port_by_id

This patch replaces regex matching of text output with parsing
of JSON output in ovs_lib.get_vif_port_by_id.
This makes the code more reliable as subtle, possibly even
cosmetic, changes in ovs-vsctl output format could cause the
regular expression match to fail.

Also, this makes the code consistent with ovs_lib.get_vif_port_set
which already uses JSON output.

Finally this patch slightly changes the behaviour of
ovs_lib.get_vif_port_by_id returning None if elements such as
mac address or ofport were not available.

Change-Id: Ia985a130739c72b5b88414a79b2c6083ca6a0a00
Closes-Bug: #1280827
'}]
commit_message:
Parse JSON in ovs_lib.get_vif_port_by_id

This patch replaces regex matching of text output with parsing
of JSON output in ovs_lib.get_vif_port_by_id.
This makes the code more reliable as subtle, possibly even
cosmetic, changes in ovs-vsctl output format could cause the
regular expression match to fail.

Also, this makes the code consistent with ovs_lib.get_vif_port_set
which already uses JSON output.

Finally this patch slightly changes the behaviour of
ovs_lib.get_vif_port_by_id returning None if elements such as
mac address or ofport were not available.

Change-Id: Ia985a130739c72b5b88414a79b2c6083ca6a0a00
Closes-Bug: #1280827
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/89/73889/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _test_get_vif_port_by_id(self, iface_id, data): headings = ['external_ids', 'name', 'ofport'] (mock.call(["ovs-vsctl", self.TO, "--format=json", 'external_ids:iface-id="%s"' % iface_id], self._encode_ovs_json(headings, data))] tools.setup_mock_calls(self.execute, expected_calls_and_values) vif_port = self.br.get_vif_port_by_id(iface_id) def _test_get_vif_port_by_id_with_data(self, ofport=None, mac=None): external_ids = [["iface-id", "tap99id"], ["iface-status", "active"]] if mac: external_ids.append(["attached-mac", mac]) data = [[["map", external_ids], "tap99", ofport if ofport else '["set",[]]']] vif_port = self._test_get_vif_port_by_id('tap99id', data) if not ofport or ofport == -1 or not mac: self.assertIsNone(vif_port) return self.assertEqual(vif_port.vif_id, 'tap99id') self.assertEqual(vif_port.vif_mac, 'aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff') self.assertEqual(vif_port.port_name, 'tap99') self.assertEqual(vif_port.ofport, ofport) def test_get_vif_by_port_id_with_ofport(self): self._test_get_vif_port_by_id_with_data( ofport=1, mac="aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff") self._test_get_vif_port_by_id_with_data(mac="aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff") def test_get_vif_by_port_id_with_invalid_ofport(self): self._test_get_vif_port_by_id_with_data( ofport=-1, mac="aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff") def test_get_vif_by_port_id_without_mac(self): self._test_get_vif_port_by_id_with_data(ofport=1) def test_get_vif_by_port_id_with_no_data(self): self.assertIsNone(self._test_get_vif_port_by_id('whatever', []))
deleted_lines:
def test_port_id_regex(self): result = ('external_ids : {attached-mac="fa:16:3e:23:5b:f2",' ' iface-id="5c1321a7-c73f-4a77-95e6-9f86402e5c8f",' ' iface-status=active}
name :' ' "dhc5c1321a7-c7"
ofport : 2
') match = self.br.re_id.search(result) vif_mac = match.group('vif_mac') vif_id = match.group('vif_id') port_name = match.group('port_name') ofport = int(match.group('ofport')) self.assertEqual(vif_mac, 'fa:16:3e:23:5b:f2') self.assertEqual(vif_id, '5c1321a7-c73f-4a77-95e6-9f86402e5c8f') self.assertEqual(port_name, 'dhc5c1321a7-c7') self.assertEqual(ofport, 2) def _test_get_vif_port_by_id(self, ofport=None): expected_output = ('external_ids : {attached-mac="aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff", ' 'iface-id="tap99id",' 'iface-status=active, ' 'vm-uuid="tap99vm"}' '
name : "tap99"
ofport : %(ofport)s
') (mock.call(["ovs-vsctl", self.TO, 'external_ids:iface-id="tap99id"'], expected_output % {'ofport': ofport or '[]'}), ] tools.setup_mock_calls(self.execute, expected_calls_and_values) vif_port = self.br.get_vif_port_by_id('tap99id') self.assertEqual(vif_port.vif_id, 'tap99id') self.assertEqual(vif_port.vif_mac, 'aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff') self.assertEqual(vif_port.port_name, 'tap99') def test_get_vif_by_port_id_with_ofport(self): vif_port = self._test_get_vif_port_by_id('1') self.assertEqual(vif_port.ofport, 1) vif_port = self._test_get_vif_port_by_id() self.assertIsNone(vif_port.ofport)

commit_message:
Swiftclient should switch to using bufferedhttp

Swiftclient should switch to using bufferedhttp like in swift which
makes up for missing features in traditional httplib, for eg)
buffering http headers, support for 'Expect: 100-continue' etc.
This patch pulls in the bufferedhttp from swift.

Related to bp use-bufferedhttp-in-swiftclient
Change-Id: I65f0b0f62f5d89bc8dd24b1260531e1f1d3555c8

added_lines: from eventlet.green.httplib import CONTINUE, HTTPConnection, HTTPMessage, \ HTTPResponse, HTTPSConnection, _UNKNOWN try: from swiftclient.bufferedhttp \ import BufferedHTTPConnection as HTTPConnection except ImportError: try: from eventlet.green.httplib import HTTPConnection except ImportError: from httplib import HTTPConnection conn = BufferedHTTPConnection(host)
deleted_lines: from httplib import HTTPException, HTTPConnection, HTTPSConnection conn = HTTPConnection(host)

subject: Fix GETs of SLOs and DLOs with If-Modified-Since
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-14 00:05:17.000000000', 'files': ['swift/common/utils.py', 'swift/common/middleware/slo.py', 'test/unit/common/middleware/test_slo.py', 'test/unit/common/middleware/test_dlo.py', 'swift/common/middleware/dlo.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/22138699cac701e8cfb3399e0d34407faa8db180', 'message': "Fix GETs of SLOs and DLOs with If-Modified-Since

Both SLO and DLO will raise errors if they try to fetch a segment and
get a non-2xx response. Well, if the client passed in an
If-Modified-Since or If-Unmodified-Since header, that'd get passed
along for all the segment requests, and if that happened to result in
a 304, then it's error time.

Now SLO and DLO strip those headers off for submanifest requests
(SLO), container listing requests (DLO), and segment requests (both).

Change-Id: I0432bbe8404159dab1485e57eaf9e111de486baa
Closes-Bug: 1280022
Closes-Bug: 1280028
"}]
commit_message:
Fix GETs of SLOs and DLOs with If-Modified-Since

Both SLO and DLO will raise errors if they try to fetch a segment and
get a non-2xx response. Well, if the client passed in an
If-Modified-Since or If-Unmodified-Since header, that'd get passed
along for all the segment requests, and if that happened to result in
a 304, then it's error time.

Now SLO and DLO strip those headers off for submanifest requests
(SLO), container listing requests (DLO), and segment requests (both).

Change-Id: I0432bbe8404159dab1485e57eaf9e111de486baa
Closes-Bug: 1280022
Closes-Bug: 1280028
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/48/73448/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: con_req.if_modified_since = None con_req.if_unmodified_since = None

subject: Adds clarity to the usage of the authorisation token
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-19 20:06:11.000000000', 'files': ['doc/install-guide/section_keystone-users.xml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/ee63789be033329466aa6543548b3520aba1ab4e', 'message': 'Adds clarity to the usage of the authorisation token

As reported in LP#1277289, the usage of the authorisation
token is not clear in the instructions. It refers to a token
previously created but potentially leaves the user
confused as to which one to use. This patch adds the clarity
required and posts a link to the documentation section.

Change-Id: Ib16bd2770d4c4aac5292e9a3d2f25c2417e818f2
Closes-Bug: #1277289

(cherry picked from commit c2e6c077f31d29bd21e743a2ded36916857b14bb)

commit_message:
Adds clarity to the usage of the authorisation token

As reported in LP#1277289, the usage of the authorisation
token is not clear in the instructions. It refers to a token
previously created but potentially leaves the user
confused as to which one to use. This patch adds the clarity
required and posts a link to the documentation section.

Change-Id: Ib16bd2770d4c4aac5292e9a3d2f25c2417e818f2
Closes-Bug: #1277289
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit c2e6c077f31d29bd21e743a2ded36916857b14bb)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/19/74819/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: token created in an earlier step, see <xref linkend="keystone-install"/> for further details. You can pass this with the <userinput><replaceable>ADMIN_TOKEN</replaceable></userinput> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>export OS_SERVICE_TOKEN=<replaceable>ADMIN_TOKEN</replaceable></userinput>
deleted_lines: token created in the previous section. You can pass this with the <userinput><replaceable>FCAF3E...</replaceable></userinput> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>export OS_SERVICE_TOKEN=<replaceable>FCAF3E...</replaceable></userinput>

subject: Convert Token Memcache backend to new KeyValueStore Impl
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2013-12-09 05:38:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/18639d031b337ec4f6dfd862efd09321ac140e57', 'message': 'Convert Token Memcache backend to new KeyValueStore Impl

This patchset converts the memcache backend for tokens to the new
KeyValueStore implementation.  This implementation provides basic
configuration choices for utilizing memcache as a token backend.

The test_backend_memcache test suite has been removed, as there is
no extra functionality added on top of the KeyValueStore base
besides the basic configuration choices.  The test_backend_memcache
test suite was only used for testing token memcache backend.  The
important unicode tests have been moved into the base token test
suite and should now validate against all token backends.

bp: dogpile-kvs-backends

commit_message:
Convert Token Memcache backend to new KeyValueStore Impl

This patchset converts the memcache backend for tokens to the new
KeyValueStore implementation.  This implementation provides basic
configuration choices for utilizing memcache as a token backend.

The test_backend_memcache test suite has been removed, as there is
no extra functionality added on top of the KeyValueStore base
besides the basic configuration choices.  The test_backend_memcache
test suite was only used for testing token memcache backend.  The
important unicode tests have been moved into the base token test
suite and should now validate against all token backends.

Closes-Bug: #1260080
bp: dogpile-kvs-backends
Change-Id: I8f0bca409a6393176e77f7a27ba15959756da06f

added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright 2013 Metacloud, Inc.from keystone.common import config from keystone.token.backends import kvs class Token(kvs.Token): kvs_backend = 'openstack.kvs.Memcached' def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): kwargs['no_expiry_keys'] = self.revocation_key kwargs['memcached_expire_time'] = CONF.token.expiration kwargs['url'] = CONF.memcache.servers super(Token, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)
deleted_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 from __future__ import absolute_import import copy import memcache from keystone.common import utils from keystone import config from keystone import exception from keystone.openstack.common import jsonutils from keystone.openstack.common import log as logging from keystone.openstack.common import timeutils from keystone import tokenLOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class Token(token.Driver): revocation_key = 'revocation-list' def __init__(self, client=None): self._memcache_client = client @property def client(self): return self._memcache_client or self._get_memcache_client() def _get_memcache_client(self): memcache_servers = CONF.memcache.servers # NOTE(morganfainberg): The memcache client library for python is NOT # thread safe and should not be passed between threads. This is highly # specific to the cas() (compare and set) methods and the caching of # the previous value(s). It appears greenthread should ensure there is # a single data structure per spawned greenthread. self._memcache_client = memcache.Client(memcache_servers, debug=0, cache_cas=True) return self._memcache_client def _prefix_token_id(self, token_id): return 'token-%s' % token_id.encode('utf-8') def _prefix_user_id(self, user_id): return 'usertokens-%s' % user_id.encode('utf-8') def get_token(self, token_id): if token_id is None: raise exception.TokenNotFound(token_id='') ptk = self._prefix_token_id(token_id) token_ref = self.client.get(ptk) if token_ref is None: raise exception.TokenNotFound(token_id=token_id) return token_ref def create_token(self, token_id, data): data_copy = copy.deepcopy(data) ptk = self._prefix_token_id(token_id) if not data_copy.get('expires'): data_copy['expires'] = token.default_expire_time() if not data_copy.get('user_id'): data_copy['user_id'] = data_copy['user']['id'] kwargs = {} if data_copy['expires'] is not None: expires_ts = utils.unixtime(data_copy['expires']) kwargs['time'] = expires_ts self.client.set(ptk, data_copy, **kwargs) if 'id' in data['user']: token_data = jsonutils.dumps(token_id) user_id = data['user']['id'] user_key = self._prefix_user_id(user_id) # Append the new token_id to the token-index-list stored in the # user-key within memcache. self._update_user_list_with_cas(user_key, token_data) return copy.deepcopy(data_copy) def _update_user_list_with_cas(self, user_key, token_id): cas_retry = 0 max_cas_retry = CONF.memcache.max_compare_and_set_retry current_time = timeutils.normalize_time( timeutils.parse_isotime(timeutils.isotime())) self.client.reset_cas() while cas_retry <= max_cas_retry: # NOTE(morganfainberg): cas or "compare and set" is a function of # memcache. It will return false if the value has changed since the # last call to client.gets(). This is the memcache supported method # of avoiding race conditions on set(). Memcache is already atomic # on the back-end and serializes operations. # # cas_retry is for tracking our iterations before we give up (in # case memcache is down or something horrible happens we don't # iterate forever trying to compare and set the new value. cas_retry += 1 record = self.client.gets(user_key) filtered_list = [] if record is not None: token_list = jsonutils.loads('[%s]' % record) for token_i in token_list: ptk = self._prefix_token_id(token_i) token_ref = self.client.get(ptk) if not token_ref: # skip tokens that do not exist in memcache continue if 'expires' in token_ref: expires_at = timeutils.normalize_time( token_ref['expires']) if expires_at < current_time: # skip tokens that are expired. continue # Add the still valid token_id to the list. filtered_list.append(jsonutils.dumps(token_i)) # Add the new token_id to the list. filtered_list.append(token_id) # Use compare-and-set (cas) to set the new value for the # token-index-list for the user-key. Cas is used to prevent race # conditions from causing the loss of valid token ids from this # list. if self.client.cas(user_key, ','.join(filtered_list)): msg = _('Successful set of token-index-list for user-key ' '"%(user_key)s", #%(count)d records') LOG.debug(msg, {'user_key': user_key, 'count': len(filtered_list)}) return filtered_list # The cas function will return true if it succeeded or false if it # failed for any reason, including memcache server being down, cas # id changed since gets() called (the data changed between when # this loop started and this point, etc. error_msg = _('Failed to set token-index-list for user-key ' '"%(user_key)s". Attempt %(cas_retry)d of ' '%(cas_retry_max)d') LOG.debug(error_msg, {'user_key': user_key, 'cas_retry': cas_retry, 'cas_retry_max': max_cas_retry}) # Exceeded the maximum retry attempts. error_msg = _('Unable to add token user list') raise exception.UnexpectedError(error_msg) def _add_to_revocation_list(self, data): data_json = jsonutils.dumps(data) if not self.client.append(self.revocation_key, ',%s' % data_json): if not self.client.add(self.revocation_key, data_json): if not self.client.append(self.revocation_key, ',%s' % data_json): msg = _('Unable to add token to revocation list.') raise exception.UnexpectedError(msg) def delete_token(self, token_id): # Test for existence data = self.get_token(token_id) ptk = self._prefix_token_id(token_id) result = self.client.delete(ptk) self._add_to_revocation_list(data) return result def delete_tokens(self, user_id, tenant_id=None, trust_id=None, consumer_id=None): return super(Token, self).delete_tokens( user_id=user_id, tenant_id=tenant_id, trust_id=trust_id, consumer_id=consumer_id, ) def _list_tokens(self, user_id, tenant_id=None, trust_id=None, consumer_id=None): tokens = [] user_key = self._prefix_user_id(user_id) user_record = self.client.get(user_key) or "" token_list = jsonutils.loads('[%s]' % user_record) for token_id in token_list: ptk = self._prefix_token_id(token_id) token_ref = self.client.get(ptk) if token_ref: if tenant_id is not None: tenant = token_ref.get('tenant') if not tenant: continue if tenant.get('id') != tenant_id: continue if trust_id is not None: trust = token_ref.get('trust_id') if not trust: continue if trust != trust_id: continue if consumer_id is not None: try: oauth = token_ref['token_data']['token']['OS-OAUTH1'] if oauth.get('consumer_id') != consumer_id: continue except KeyError: continue tokens.append(token_id) return tokens def list_revoked_tokens(self): list_json = self.client.get(self.revocation_key) if list_json: return jsonutils.loads('[%s]' % list_json) return [] def flush_expired_tokens(self): """Archive or delete tokens that have expired. """ raise exception.NotImplemented()

commit_message:
Add check_uptodate.sh to run_tests.sh -p

Now, check_uptodate.sh is executed by 'tox -epep8' or using it directly.
We have run_tests.sh for convenience and many developers use it for
checking their code. So we should also have 'check_uptodate.sh' in
run_tests.sh.
This commit adds check_uptodate.sh to 'run_tests.sh -p'

Change-Id: I4c994e0589cfd6cb213aed5acd232670fc320a26

commit_message:
Invalid client version message unclear

The error message when using an invalid os-compute-api-version is
created by joining all the available versions without space.
This patch will add ', ' between versions.

Ex: nova --os-compute-api-version v3 list
ERROR: Invalid client version 'v3'. must be one of: 321.1
Now: nova --os-compute-api-version v3 list
ERROR: Invalid client version 'v3'. must be one of: 3, 2, 1.1

Change-Id: I825df89d38adc9e4bd3fb900cd0199f159c04a6b

commit_message:
Test query-string for list actions with filter arguments

httpretty.register_uri only matches the path, not the query
string, so the test_list will pass even if the query string
passed by the manager doesn't match that passed as part of
expected_path.

So add a test for the query component of all list requests,
and a way to override the expected query, which is needed in
the trusts list filter tests where the query string doesn't
exactly match the kwargs passed to the client API.

Change-Id: I290b73bbbdac88487c225063fd3775ab7dd8bb89

commit_message:
Shift debian element to DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR

The ubuntu element supports simple replacement of sources.list by using
the DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR environment variable. Drag the debian
element into line by supporting both DIB_DEBIAN_MIRROR and the new shiny
DIB_DISTRIBUTION_MIRROR.

Change-Id: I9d5f8d1e3251965b34e55929182aa601a524fe8f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/93/73893/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: DIB_DEBIAN_MIRROR=${DIB_DEBIAN_MIRROR:-http://http.debian.net/debian} $DIB_DEBIAN_MIRROR"

commit_message:
Move filter_limit_query out of sql.Base

With the change to use oslo's db.sqlalchemy.sessions, the
sql.Base class isn't doing enough to justify its continued
existence.

This change is moving the filter_limit_query and related internal
members out of sql.Base to regular functions in the sql module.

Part of bp use-common-oslo-db-code

Change-Id: Ia4f05e5a81ded7e3543e16ecf93260680351f1e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/37/69137/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _filter(model, query, hints): """Applies filtering to a query. :param model: the table model in question :param query: query to apply filters to :param hints: contains the list of filters yet to be satisfied. Any filters satisfied here will be removed so that the caller will know if any filters remain. :returns query: query, updated with any filters satisfied """ def inexact_filter(model, query, filter_, hints): """Applies an inexact filter to a query. :param filter_: the dict that describes this filter :returns query: query updated to add any inexact filters we could satisfy column_attr = getattr(model, filter_['name']) # TODO(henry-nash): Sqlalchemy 0.7 defaults to case insensitivity # so once we find a way of changing that (maybe on a call-by-call # basis), we can add support for the case sensitive versions of # the filters below. For now, these case sensitive versions will # be handled at the controller level. if filter_['case_sensitive']: return query if filter_['comparator'] == 'contains': query_term = column_attr.ilike('%%%s%%' % filter_['value']) elif filter_['comparator'] == 'startswith': query_term = column_attr.ilike('%s%%' % filter_['value']) elif filter_['comparator'] == 'endswith': query_term = column_attr.ilike('%%%s' % filter_['value']) else: # It's a filter we don't understand, so let the caller # work out if they need to do something with it. return query hints.remove(filter_) return query.filter(query_term) def exact_filter(model, filter_, cumlative_filter_dict, hints): """Applies an exact filter to a query. :param model: the table model in question :param filter_: the dict that describes this filter :param cumlative_filter_dict: a dict that describes the set of exact filters built up so far :returns cumlative_filter_dict: updated cumulative dict key = filter_['name'] if isinstance(getattr(model, key).property.columns[0].type, sql.types.Boolean): filter_dict[key] = utils.attr_as_boolean(filter_['value']) else: filter_dict[key] = filter_['value'] hints.remove(filter_) return filter_dict filter_dict = {} for filter_ in hints.filters(): # TODO(henry-nash): Check if name is valid column, if not skip if filter_['comparator'] == 'equals': filter_dict = exact_filter(model, filter_, filter_dict, hints) else: query = inexact_filter(model, query, filter_, hints) # Apply any exact filters we built up if filter_dict: query = query.filter_by(**filter_dict) return query def filter_query(model, query, hints): """Applies filtering to a query. :param model: table model :param query: query to apply filters to :param hints: contains the list of filters yet to be satisfied. Any filters satisfied here will be removed so that the caller will know if any filters remain. :returns updated query """ if hints is not None: query = _filter(model, query, hints) return query # Backends class Base(object): pass

commit_message:
Fix assignment KVS backend to not use identity

The assignment KVS backend was using the identity API. This change
makes it so that the KVS backend does not use the identity API.

The assignment KVS backend was using the identity API to:

a) Store the user's projects.

The user's projects were also kept in the metadata. So the KVS
backend was changed to use the metadata rather than the user data.

a) Determine if the ID in the metadata was for a user or group.

The metadata for users and groups was split into separate keys.
Metadata for users is now prefixed with `metadata_user-` and
`metadata-groups-` is used for groups.

bp no-check-id

Change-Id: I5cc01d203d12b15575b72ad57aa3820d1d36d09f

subject: Implement mechanism to provide non-expiring keys in KVS
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-09 05:38:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/543f897f3d71db3e08af97507ad2c6e94ee3169e', 'message': 'Implement mechanism to provide non-expiring keys in KVS

This patchset implements a mechanism to specify non-expiring keys
for dogpile.cache backends that have a concept keys that are
automatically removed from the backend based upon an expiry value
(e.g. memcached, redis).  This new non-expiring key functionality
only will have an effect if the backend specifies an expiry for
keys.

bp: dogpile-kvs-backends

commit_message:
Implement mechanism to provide non-expiring keys in KVS

This patchset implements the ability to define non-expiring keys
for dogpile.cache backends. The non-expiring keys are relevant
in the case of drivers that can automatically remove keys after
a given time (e.g. memcache). This new non-expiring-key
functionality is currently only implemented for the provided
memcached backend.

bp: dogpile-kvs-backends
Change-Id: I7e25e0049e5b8697c5cb67272b660519c3c3305e

added_lines: # The backend should also have the keymangler set the same as the # region now. self.assertIs(kvs._region.backend.key_mangler, util.sha1_mangle_key) def test_kvs_memcache_manager_no_expiry_keys(self): # Make sure the memcache backend recalculates the no-expiry keys # correctly when a key-mangler is set on it. def new_mangler(key): return '_mangled_key_' + key kvs = self._get_kvs_region() no_expiry_keys = set(['test_key']) kvs.configure('openstack.kvs.Memcached', dogpile_memcache_backend='MemcachedBackend', no_expiry_keys=no_expiry_keys) calculated_keys = set([kvs._region.key_mangler(key) for key in no_expiry_keys]) self.assertIs(kvs._region.backend.key_mangler, util.sha1_mangle_key) self.assertSetEqual(calculated_keys, kvs._region.backend._no_expiry_keys) self.assertSetEqual(no_expiry_keys, kvs._region.backend._raw_no_expiry_keys) calculated_keys = set([new_mangler(key) for key in no_expiry_keys]) setattr(kvs._region.backend, 'key_mangler', new_mangler) self.assertSetEqual(calculated_keys, kvs._region.backend._no_expiry_keys) self.assertSetEqual(no_expiry_keys, kvs._region.backend._raw_no_expiry_keys)

commit_message:
de-hardcode adjustment type strings in autoscaling

The scaling policy adjustment types were hardcoded throughout
autoscaling.py: 'ExactCapacity', 'ChangeInCapacity', and
'PercentChangeInCapacity'. These are now constants at the module
level.

Change-Id: I0bd610e25bdba8ab13daf94b508934dca7e30c00

commit_message:
str2dict support commas within quotes

neutronclient.common.str2dict split string 'key1=value1,key2=value2' by comma
and doesn't consider commas within quotes, so the client cann't support any
value itself contains commas like 'key1=value1,key2="part1,part2"'.

Closes-Bug: #1266489

Change-Id: Ieb3a8b76ce3fbe96703c25a7a611cbc14e784bef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/97/65097/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: input_str = 'key1=value1,key2=value2,key3="value3,value4"' expected = {'key1': 'value1', 'key2': 'value2', 'key3': 'value3,value4'}
deleted_lines: input_str = 'key1=value1,key2=value2' expected = {'key1': 'value1', 'key2': 'value2'}

commit_message:
VMWare: session refactor - session validation

Introduces simplified API to start, join, or end sessions with
vSphere and uses lighter weight session controls to verify,
end, and continue sessions.

partial blueprint: vmware-soap-session-management
Change-Id: I55e2f919062163152a449b90e9c692dcc2ee1394
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/78/66378/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 VMware # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import collections import mock from nova import test from nova.virt.vmwareapi import driver from nova.virt.vmwareapi import error_util from nova.virt.vmwareapi import vim_util SudsSessionObject = collections.namedtuple('SudsSessionObject', ['key']) class VMwareAPISessionTestCase(test.NoDBTestCase): def setUp(self): super(VMwareAPISessionTestCase, self).setUp() self.mock_periodic_task = mock.patch( 'nova.openstack.common.periodic_task') self.mock_periodic_task.start() def tearDown(self): super(VMwareAPISessionTestCase, self).tearDown() self.mock_periodic_task.stop() @mock.patch('nova.virt.vmwareapi.driver.vim.Vim') def test_session_init(self, mock_vim): session = driver.VMwareAPISession() self.assertIsNotNone(session) @mock.patch('nova.virt.vmwareapi.driver.vim.Vim') def test_session_valid_mock_timeout(self, mock_vim): session = driver.VMwareAPISession() self.assertIsNotNone(session) session.vim.has_open_session.return_value = False self.assertFalse(session.valid) @mock.patch('nova.virt.vmwareapi.driver.vim.Vim') def test_session_valid(self, mock_vim): session = driver.VMwareAPISession() self.assertIsNotNone(session) session.vim.has_open_session.return_value = True self.assertTrue(session.valid) @mock.patch('nova.virt.vmwareapi.driver.vim.Vim') def test_session_valid_badly_initialized(self, mock_vim): session = driver.VMwareAPISession() self.assertIsNotNone(session) session.vim = None self.assertFalse(session.valid) @mock.patch('nova.virt.vmwareapi.driver.vim.Vim') def test_session_valid_badly_initialized(self, mock_vim): session = driver.VMwareAPISession() self.assertIsNotNone(session) session._session_id = None self.assertFalse(session.valid) @mock.patch('time.sleep') @mock.patch('nova.virt.vmwareapi.vim.Vim') def test_vim_create_session_with_timeout_testing(self, mock_vim, mock_sleep): # mocking suds.client.Client prevents us from talking actual SOAP # mocking the time.sleep object prevents us from running too long session_objects = [ SudsSessionObject(key='key-2'), error_util.VimFaultException(mock.Mock(), mock.Mock()), error_util.VimFaultException(mock.Mock(), mock.Mock()), SudsSessionObject(key='key-1'), error_util.VimFaultException(mock.Mock(), mock.Mock()), error_util.VimFaultException(mock.Mock(), mock.Mock())] def mock_login(*args, **kwargs): result = session_objects.pop() if isinstance(result, Exception): raise result return result mock_vim.Login.side_effect = mock_login session = driver.VMwareAPISession() session._session_id = None session.vim = mock_vim session._create_session() self.assertTrue(session.valid) self.assertEqual('key-1', session._session_id) session._session_id = None self.assertFalse(session.valid) session._create_session() self.assertEqual('key-2', session._session_id) self.assertTrue(session.valid) self.assertEqual(0, len(session_objects)) @mock.patch('nova.virt.vmwareapi.vim.suds.client.Client') def test_session_context_manager(self, mock_client): # mocking suds.client.Client prevents us from talking actual SOAP session_object = driver.VMwareAPISession() session_object.end() self.assertFalse(session_object.valid) # session is not open with session_object as session: # with statement has opened the session self.assertTrue(session_object.valid) self.assertTrue(session._hangup) vms = session._call_method(vim_util, "get_objects", "VirtualMachine", ["name", "runtime.connectionState"]) self.assertIsNotNone(vms) # default behavior has closed the session self.assertFalse(session_object.valid) @mock.patch('nova.virt.vmwareapi.vim.suds.client.Client') def test_session_context_manager_join(self, mock_client): # mocking suds.client.Client prevents us from talking actual SOAP session_object = driver.VMwareAPISession() session_object.end() self.assertFalse(session_object.valid) # session is not open with session_object.join() as session: # with statement has opened the session self.assertTrue(session_object.valid) self.assertFalse(session._hangup) vms = session._call_method(vim_util, "get_objects", "VirtualMachine", ["name", "runtime.connectionState"]) self.assertIsNotNone(vms) # session is still open after context has closed self.assertTrue(session_object.valid)

syslog format deprecation) which adds APP-NAME to syslog message
before MSG part to reflect application or service name.
Usable only with use_syslog, otherwise ignored.

During J, the default logging format for syslog should be changed
to always provide APP-NAME, thus use_syslog_rfc_format could be
deprecated in J as well.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ia704e0735a38f0e9f6ad7a2d7c827c21e6637a31

commit_message:
Sync log.py from oslo

This change syncs log.py from oslo-incubator with commit
79e8a9a08daf563aa8a8d9280c9a6a27dcafc8f2

To honor RFC5424 add use_syslog_rfc_format config option
(default False, would be deprecated in J after existing
syslog format deprecation) which adds APP-NAME to syslog message
before MSG part to reflect application or service name.
Usable only with use_syslog, otherwise ignored.

During J, the default logging format for syslog should be changed
to always provide APP-NAME, thus use_syslog_rfc_format could be
deprecated in J as well.

DocImpact

Closes-bug: 904307

Change-Id: Ia704e0735a38f0e9f6ad7a2d7c827c21e6637a31
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/72/74572/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: help='Use syslog for logging. ' 'Existing syslog format is DEPRECATED during I, ' 'and then will be changed in J to honor RFC5424'), cfg.BoolOpt('use-syslog-rfc-format', # TODO(bogdando) remove or use True after existing # syslog format deprecation in J default=False, help='(Optional) Use syslog rfc5424 format for logging. ' 'If enabled, will add APP-NAME (RFC5424) before the ' 'MSG part of the syslog message. The old format ' 'without APP-NAME is deprecated in I, ' 'and will be removed in J.'),class RFCSysLogHandler(logging.handlers.SysLogHandler): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): self.binary_name = _get_binary_name() super(RFCSysLogHandler, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) def format(self, record): msg = super(RFCSysLogHandler, self).format(record) msg = self.binary_name + ' ' + msg return msg # TODO(bogdando) use the format provided by RFCSysLogHandler # after existing syslog format deprecation in J if CONF.use_syslog_rfc_format: syslog = RFCSysLogHandler(address='/dev/log', facility=facility) else: syslog = logging.handlers.SysLogHandler(address='/dev/log', facility=facility)
deleted_lines: help='Use syslog for logging.'), syslog = logging.handlers.SysLogHandler(address='/dev/log', facility=facility)

added_lines: <sidebar><title>Multithread Considerations</title> <para>Hyper-threading is Intel's proprietary simultaneous multithreading implementation used to improve parallelization on their CPUs. You might consider enabling hyper-threading to improve the performance of multi-threaded applications.</para> to determine what is more appropriate in your case.</para></sidebar> <para>A hypervisor provides software to manage virtual machine access to the underlying hardware. The hypervisor creates, manages, and monitors virtual machines. OpenStack Compute supports many hypervisors to various degrees, including: core. For example, if a physical node has 12 cores, then the scheduler sees 192 available virtual cores. With typical flavor definitions of 4 virtual cores per instance, this ratio would provide 48 instances on a physical node.</para>

commit_message:
Make libvirt use Flavor object instead of using VirtAPI

This makes the libvirt driver use the Flavor object instead of
getting that information through the VirtAPI/conductor call.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: I484c98068a46c9780d82c886779eb58e783f9b6f

deleted_lines: inst_type = self.virtapi.flavor_get( inst_type) inst_type = self.virtapi.flavor_get( cfg = self.vif_driver.get_config(instance, vif, None, inst_type) inst_type = self.virtapi.flavor_get( guest.memory = inst_type['memory_mb'] * units.Ki guest.vcpus = inst_type['vcpus'] for key, value in inst_type['extra_specs'].iteritems(): inst_type): inst_type)

commit_message:
Fix some test comments related to quota_set

Non-admin users can get the quota_set resource of the tenant which
they belong to, and the tests do it now. However the comments show
admin tests. This patch fixes the comments.

Change-Id: I814043e6fd07a1128a5ebb543ea4e75ba6a112f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/71/74271/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # User can get the default resource quota set for the tenant
deleted_lines: # Admin can get the default resource quota set for a tenant

commit_message:
Variable 'domain_ref' referenced before assignment

Variable not declared before try...catch sentences trigger a
"Local variable 'domain_ref' referenced before assignment" error when
an exception is raised.

Co-Authored-By: David Stanek <dstanek@dstanek.com>
Change-Id: I0a63347cb316e3a5923243dd934a7fc51dbf1e13
Closes-Bug: #1274402
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/69/70069/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: domain_ref = None

subject: Make max-online-resize an option.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-16 04:14:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/2076d62ca75974119488ed49cbd9e6cf0af630be', 'message': "Make max-online-resize an option.

In fb246a02eb2ed330d3cc37f5795b3ed026aabe07 we introduced an
ext4 option to allow root filesystems to be resized up to 1PB.
This appears to cause an ext4 resize2fs bug in some images.

When the issue occurs an image will hit a kernel bug when
cloud-init runs the resize2fs command during first boot:

  kernel BUG at fs/ext4/resize.c:409!

In this commit we add a new option for max-online-resize
which can be used if a really large root partition is
desirable.

The root cause of all this is really a design problem in
DIB/TripleO at the moment in that we shouldn't have to worry about the
max size of the root file system when creating our images. Ideally we'd
just mkfs on the root file system itself. Much more efficient, and
avoids this problem altogether...

I think the best thing to do today to avoid this is make setting
max-online-resize an option in DIB. This will allow us to stick to the
(well tested) ext4 defaults for most cases, and if someone has need for
a large root filesystem they can easily bump the setting. This may be
temporary until we either fix the design... or the ext4 fix is released.

Change-Id: I371f62555d2753cec48790c8fd811c4342af925c
Closes-bug: #1280709
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-02-17 18:21:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/3598b612e41801d3fd4d5f6a52675094c0a7b294', 'message': "Remove ext4 resize= option.

In fb246a02eb2ed330d3cc37f5795b3ed026aabe07 we introduced an
ext4 option to allow root filesystems to be resized up to 1PB.

This causes an ext4 resize2fs bug in some images.
When the issue occurs an image will hit a kernel bug when
cloud-init runs the resize2fs command during first boot:

  kernel BUG at fs/ext4/resize.c:409!

In this commit we drop the option entirely since file
system resizes were never intended to be used in this manner
(i.e going from a 2GB to a 1PB filesystem).

The root cause of all this is really a design problem in
DIB/TripleO at the moment in that we shouldn't have to worry about the
max size of the root file system when creating our images. Ideally we'd
just mkfs on the root file system itself. Much more efficient, and
avoids this problem altogether... So this is really something
that should be fixed in Nova/Ironic. Not DIB.

Furthermore, A reasonable amount of resizability (1000 times) is
automatically accounted for w/ mkfs.ext4 so lets
just go with that... (this works well w/ resize2fs anyways)
and is what we use for cloudy images anyways.

Change-Id: I371f62555d2753cec48790c8fd811c4342af925c
Partial-bug: #1280709
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-02-17 19:42:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/8596fe0350405831fec46e53de080cf8f609fb77', 'message': "Make max-online-resize an option.

ext4 option to allow root filesystems to be resized up to 1PB.
This appears to cause an ext4 resize2fs bug in some images.

When the issue occurs an image will hit a kernel bug when
cloud-init runs the resize2fs command during first boot:

  kernel BUG at fs/ext4/resize.c:409!

In this commit we add a new option for max-online-resize
which can be used if a really large root partition is
desirable.

The root cause of all this is really a design problem in
DIB/TripleO at the moment in that we shouldn't have to worry about the
max size of the root file system when creating our images.  Ideally we'd
just mkfs on the root file system itself. Much more efficient,
avoids this problem altogether...

I think the best thing to do today to avoid this is make setting
max-online-resize an option in DIB. This will allow us to stick
to the (well tested) ext4 defaults for most cases, and if someone has
need for a large root filesystem they can easily bump the setting. This
may be temporary until we either fix the design... or the ext4 fix is
released.

Change-Id: I371f62555d2753cec48790c8fd811c4342af925c
Partial-bug: #1280709
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-02-19 06:50:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/73969c106a5a6713008aa6ae225cd6d6d52e3a24', 'message': 'Make max-online-resize an option.

In fb246a02eb2ed330d3cc37f5795b3ed026aabe07 we introduced an
ext4 option to allow root filesystems to be resized up to 1PB.
This triggers an ext4 resize2fs bug in some images.

When the issue occurs an image will hit a kernel bug when
cloud-init runs the resize2fs command during first boot:

  kernel BUG at fs/ext4/resize.c:409!

In this commit we add a new option for max-online-resize
which can be used if a really large root partition is
desirable.

If/when ext4 is fixed we can consider whether to move this back

Change-Id: I371f62555d2753cec48790c8fd811c4342af925c

I think the best thing to do today to avoid this is make setting
max-online-resize an option in DIB. This will allow us to stick
to the (well tested) ext4 defaults for most cases, and if someone has
need for a large root filesystem they can easily bump the setting. This
may be temporary until we either fix the design... or the ext4 fix is
released.

Change-Id: I371f62555d2753cec48790c8fd811c4342af925c
Closes-bug: #1280709
"}]
commit_message:
Make max-online-resize an option.

In fb246a02eb2ed330d3cc37f5795b3ed026aabe07 we introduced an
ext4 option to allow root filesystems to be resized up to 1PB.
This appears to cause an ext4 resize2fs bug in some images.

When the issue occurs an image will hit a kernel bug when
cloud-init runs the resize2fs command during first boot:

  kernel BUG at fs/ext4/resize.c:409!

In this commit we add a new option for max-online-resize
which can be used if a really large root partition is
desirable.

The root cause of all this is really a design problem in
DIB/TripleO at the moment in that we shouldn't have to worry about the
max size of the root file system when creating our images.  Ideally we'd
just mkfs on the root file system itself. Much more efficient,
avoids this problem altogether...

I think the best thing to do today to avoid this is make setting
max-online-resize an option in DIB. This will allow us to stick
to the (well tested) ext4 defaults for most cases, and if someone has
need for a large root filesystem they can easily bump the setting. This
may be temporary until we either fix the design... or the ext4 fix is
released.

Change-Id: I371f62555d2753cec48790c8fd811c4342af925c
Closes-bug: #1280709
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/54/73854/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo " --max-online-resize size -- max number of filesystem blocks to supported when resizing. Useful if you want a really large root partition when the image is deployed."TEMP=`getopt -o a:ho:xucnp: -l no-tmpfs,offline,help,min-tmpfs,image-size,max-online-resize: -n $SCRIPTNAME -- "$@"` --max-online-resize) export MAX_ONLINE_RESIZE=$2; shift 2;; if [ -n "$MAX_ONLINE_RESIZE" ]; then # To allow up to 1PB (of 4KB blocks) set to 274877906944 MKFS_OPTS="$MKFS_OPTS -E resize=$MAX_ONLINE_RESIZE" fi
deleted_lines: TEMP=`getopt -o a:ho:xucnp: -l no-tmpfs,offline,help,min-tmpfs,image-size: -n $SCRIPTNAME -- "$@"`# allow up to 1PB of 4KB blocks. MKFS_OPTS="$MKFS_OPTS -E resize=274877906944"

commit_message:
Nova-baremetal support for openSUSE

Restrict package hacks to Fedora, they're not necessary
on openSUSE. Remove extranous chown nova:nova in dnsmasq
startup, the nova-baremetal scripts already take care of
that (and do it with the correct user for openSUSE)

Change-Id: I59e0553460be8a8e1f075be6eba375b77f6b5523

commit_message:
Don't lose AttributeError in API Wrappers

Instead of (implicitly) catching the AttributeError, and later
creating and raising a new one, we just re-raise the original
exception. This way all the information from the original is
retained, including the name of the actual object on which it
happened.

Change-Id: Idc0c5a8ed5dfca6a8724e393c220baf9960564ed
Closes-bug: #1274097
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/57/69857/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __getattribute__(self, attr): try: return super(APIResourceWrapper, self).__getattribute__(attr) except AttributeError: if attr not in self._attrs: raise def __getattribute__(self, attr): try: return super(APIDictWrapper, self).__getattribute__(attr) except AttributeError: if attr not in self._apidict: raise return getattr(self, item) return getattr(self, item)
deleted_lines: def __getattr__(self, attr): if attr in self._attrs: else: msg = ('Attempted to access unknown attribute "%s" on ' 'APIResource object of type "%s" wrapping resource of ' 'type "%s".') % (attr, self.__class__, self._apiresource.__class__) LOG.debug(exceptions.error_color(msg)) raise AttributeError(attr) def __getattr__(self, attr): try: except KeyError: msg = 'Unknown attribute "%(attr)s" on APIResource object ' \ 'of type "%(cls)s"' % {'attr': attr, 'cls': self.__class__} LOG.debug(exceptions.error_color(msg)) raise AttributeError(msg) return self.__getattr__(item) return self.__getattr__(item)

Remove None for dict.get()

Because If no default value is specified it defaults to None already.

commit_message:
Rationalize the Assignment Grant Tables

Currently there are four different tables in the assignment sql
backend, one for each type of grant.  This leads to significantly
more complex code.

This patch rationalizes these four tables into a single Assignment
table, with the minimal of rework to calling functions of the
sql backend.  A subsequent patch will improve efficiency of the
calling code by taking advantage of a single Assignment table.

Blueprint: role-assignments-unified-sql

Change-Id: I7e604d718b29ad28b4d59458c7a528c01ff9804d

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-14 00:39:22.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/common/rest_client.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/ac8dc997de6225a5e9c03c04dbc08d7053ffbf22', 'message': "Fix request id log messages

Previously when logging request ids tempest would incorrectly print
which service the request id came from. This was based on the faulty
assumption that x-compute-request-id was only returned by nova. It's
returned by both nova v2 and cinder. Also originally
x-openstack-request-id was only used by glance but other projects have
adopted it as well. Moving forward all the services will converge on

commit_message:
Fix request id log messages

Previously when logging request ids tempest would incorrectly print
which service the request id came from. This was based on the faulty
assumption that x-compute-request-id was only returned by nova. It's
returned by both nova v2 and cinder. Also originally
x-openstack-request-id was only used by glance but other projects have
adopted it as well. Moving forward all the services will converge on
using that header. This commit just updates the log messages to make
what is written to the log consistent with the current state of the
header.

Change-Id: Idd0514794768840c2c9911ad189552cf455ea849
